{{Selfref|For assistance with IPA transcriptions of Japanese for Wikipedia articles, see [[Help:IPA/Japanese]].}} {{Refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{IPA notice}} {{inline audio}} The [[phonology]] of [[Japanese language|Japanese]] has about 15 [[consonant]] [[phoneme]]s, the cross-linguistically typical five-[[vowel]] system of {{IPA|/a, e, i, o, u/}}, and a relatively simple [[phonotactic]] distribution of phonemes allowing few [[consonant cluster]]s. It is traditionally described as having [[mora (linguistics)|mora]]s as the unit of [[Isochrony|timing]], with each mora taking up about the same length of time, so that the disyllabic {{IPA|[ɲip.poɴ]}} ("Japan") may be analyzed as {{IPA|/niQpoN/}} and dissected into four moras, {{IPA|/ni/}}, {{IPA|/Q/}}, {{IPA|/po/}}, and {{IPA|/N/}}. Standard Japanese is a [[pitch-accent language]], wherein the position or absence of a pitch drop may determine the meaning of a word: {{IPA|/haꜜsiɡa/}} "chopsticks", {{IPA|/hasiꜜɡa/}} "bridge", {{IPA|/hasiɡa/}} "edge" (see [[Japanese pitch accent]]). Unless otherwise noted, the following describes the standard variety of Japanese based on the [[Tokyo dialect]]. ==Consonants== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! ! [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! [[Alveolo-palatal consonant|Alveolo-
palatal]] ! [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! [[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! [[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | {{IPA link|m}} | {{IPA link|n}} | ({{IPA link|ɲ̟|ɲ}}) | | ({{IPA link|ŋ}}) | ({{IPA link|ɴ}}) | |- ! [[Stop consonant|Stop]] | {{IPA link|p}}  {{IPA link|b}} | {{IPA link|t}}  {{IPA link|d}} | | | {{IPA link|k}}  {{IPA link|ɡ}} | | |- ! [[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | | ({{IPA link|t͡s}})  ({{IPA link|d͡z}}) | ({{IPA link|t͡ɕ}})  ({{IPA link|d͡ʑ}}) | | | | |- ! [[fricative consonant|Fricative]] | ({{IPA link|ɸ}}) | {{IPA link|s}}  {{IPA link|z}} | ({{IPA link|ɕ}})  ({{IPA link|ʑ}}) | ({{IPA link|ç}}) | | | {{IPA link|h}} |- ! [[Liquid consonant|Liquid]] | | {{IPA link|ɾ|r}} | | | | | |- ! [[Semivowel]] | | | | {{IPA link|j}} | {{IPA link|ɰᵝ|w}} | | |- ! Special moras | colspan="7" | [[#Moraic nasal|{{IPA|/N/}}]], [[#Gemination|{{IPA|/Q/}}]] |} '''Notes:''' *Voiceless stops {{IPA|/p, t, k/}} are slightly [[Aspirated consonant|aspirated]]: less aspirated than English stops, but more so than Spanish.{{sfnp|Riney|Takagi|Ota|Uchida|2007}} {{IPA|/p/}}, a remnant of [[Old Japanese]], now occurs only medially in [[Sino-Japanese vocabulary|Sino-Japanese]] compounds, only medially in a few fossil words as a result of the contractions of pronunciations over time (such as [[wikt:河童|河童]] ''kappa''), as well as in [[onomatopoeia]]; as ''[[gairaigo]]'', loanwords of non-Middle Chinese origin, enter the language, {{IPA|/p/}} is increasingly used in [[Transcription into Japanese|transcription]]. {{IPA|/t, d, n/}} are [[Laminal consonant|laminal]] denti-alveolar (that is, the blade of the tongue contacts the back of the upper teeth and the front part of the [[alveolar ridge]]) and {{IPA|/s, z/}} are laminal alveolar. {{IPA|/w/}} is the [[Semivowel|semivocalic]] equivalent of {{IPA|/u/}}, {{IPA|[ɰ]}}, with little to no rounding. *Consonants inside parentheses are allophones of other phonemes, at least in native words. In loanwords, {{IPA|/ɸ, ɕ, ʑ, t͡s, d͡z, t͡ɕ, d͡ʑ/}} sometimes occur phonemically, outside of the allophonic variation described below.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=59}} See below for more in-detail descriptions of allophonic variation. *Before {{IPA|/i/}}, {{IPA|/s, t/}} are [[alveolo-palatal]] {{IPA|[ɕ, t͡ɕ]}}, and {{IPA|/z, d/}} are either [[Neutralization (linguistics)|neutralized]] as [[free variation]] between {{IPA|[ʑ]}} and {{IPA|[d͡ʑ]}} or distinct as {{IPA|[ʑ, d͡ʑ]}}. Before {{IPA|/u/}}, {{IPA|/t/}} is {{IPA|[t͡s]}}, and {{IPA|/d/}} is either merged with {{IPA|/z/}} as free variation between {{IPA|[z]}} and {{IPA|[d͡z]}} or always {{IPA|[d͡z]}} distinct from {{IPA|/z/}}. When geminated, however, {{IPA|/z/}} is always {{IPA|[d͡z]}}.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=108}} *{{IPA|/h/}} is {{IPAblink|ç}} before {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/j/}} {{pronunciation|Hi (Japanese).ogg|listen|(|help=no}}, and {{IPAblink|ɸ}} before {{IPA|/u/}} {{pronunciation|Ja-Fu.oga|listen|(|help=no}},{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} coarticulated with the labial compression of that vowel. *{{IPA|/N/}} is a syllable-final [[#Moraic nasal|moraic nasal]] with variable pronunciation depending on what follows. *Realization of the liquid phoneme {{IPA|/r/}} varies greatly depending on environment and dialect. The prototypical and most common pronunciation is an apical tap, either alveolar {{IPAblink|ɾ}} or postalveolar {{IPAblink|ɾ̠}}.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=92}}{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=89}}{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} Utterance-initially and after {{IPA|/N/}}, the tap is typically articulated in such a way that the tip of the tongue is at first momentarily in light contact with the alveolar ridge before being released rapidly by airflow.{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=106}}{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=89}} This sound is described variably as a tap, a "variant of {{IPA|[ɾ]}}", "a kind of weak plosive",{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=106}} and "an affricate with short friction".{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} The [[Dental, alveolar and postalveolar lateral approximants|apico-alveolar or postalveolar lateral approximant]] {{IPA|[l]}} is a common variant in all conditions,{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} particularly utterance-initially{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=106}} and before {{IPA|/i, j/}}.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=92}} According to {{harvcoltxt|Akamatsu|1997}}, utterance-initially and intervocalically (that is, except after {{IPA|/N/}}), the lateral variant is better described as a [[Alveolar lateral flap|tap]] {{IPA|[ɺ]}} rather than an approximant.{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=106}}{{harvcoltxt|Akamatsu|1997}} employs a different symbol, {{IPA|[l̆]}}, for the lateral tap. The [[retroflex lateral approximant]] {{IPA|[ɭ]}} is also found before {{IPA|/i, j/}}.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=92}} In Tokyo's [[Tokyo dialect|Shitamachi dialect]], the [[alveolar trill]] {{IPA|[r]}} is a variant marked with vulgarity.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=92}} Other reported variants include the [[alveolar approximant]] {{IPA|[ɹ]}},{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} the [[Voiced alveolar stop|alveolar stop]] {{IPA|[d]}}, the [[retroflex flap]] {{IPA|[ɽ]}}, the [[Voiced lateral fricative|lateral fricative]] {{IPA|[ɮ]}},{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=92}} and the [[Voiced retroflex stop|retroflex stop]] {{IPA|[ɖ]}}.{{sfnp|Arai|Warner|Greenberg|2007|p=48}} ===Weakening=== Non-[[coronal consonant|coronal]] [[voiced consonant|voiced]] [[stop consonant|stops]] {{IPA|/b, ɡ/}} between vowels may be weakened to [[fricative]]s, especially in fast or casual speech: :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/b/}} > [[Voiced bilabial fricative|bilabial fricative]] {{IPA|[β]}}: | {{IPA|/abareru/}} > {{IPA|[aβaɾeɾɯ]}} ''abareru'' {{lang|ja|暴れる}} 'to behave violently' |- | {{IPA|/ɡ/}} > [[Voiced velar fricative|velar fricative]] {{IPA|[ɣ]}}: | {{IPA|/haɡe/}} > {{IPA|[haɣe]}} ''hage'' {{lang|ja|はげ}} 'baldness' |} However, {{IPA|/ɡ/}} is further complicated by its variant realization as a [[velar nasal]] {{IPA|[ŋ]}}. Standard Japanese speakers can be categorized into 3 groups (A, B, C), which will be explained below. If a speaker pronounces a given word consistently with the [[allophone]] {{IPA|[ŋ]}} (i.e. a B-speaker), that speaker will never have {{IPA|[ɣ]}} as an allophone in that same word. If a speaker varies between {{IPA|[ŋ]}} and {{IPA|[ɡ]}} (i.e. an A-speaker) or is generally consistent in using {{IPA|[ɡ]}} (i.e. a C-speaker), then the velar fricative {{IPA|[ɣ]}} is always another possible allophone in fast speech. {{IPA|/ɡ/}} may be weakened to nasal {{IPA|[ŋ]}} when it occurs within words—this includes not only between vowels but also between a vowel and a consonant. There is a fair amount of variation between speakers, however. {{harvcoltxt|Vance|1987}} suggests that the variation follows social class,{{sfnp|Vance|1987|pp=110–1}} while {{harvcoltxt|Akamatsu|1997}} suggests that the variation follows age and geographic location.{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=130}} The generalized situation is as follows. ;At the beginning of words: * all present-day standard Japanese speakers generally use the stop {{IPA|[ɡ]}} at the beginning of words: {{IPA|/ɡaijuu/}} > {{IPA|[ɡaijɯɯ]}} ''gaiyū'' {{lang|ja|外遊}} 'overseas trip' (but not {{IPA|*[ŋaijɯɯ]}}) ;In the middle of simple words (i.e. non-[[Compound (linguistics)|compounds]]): * '''A'''. a majority of speakers uses either {{IPA|[ŋ]}} or {{IPA|[ɡ]}} in free variation: {{IPA|/kaɡu/}} > {{IPA|[kaŋɯ]}} or {{IPA|[kaɡɯ]}} ''kagu'' {{lang|ja|家具}} 'furniture' * '''B'''. a minority of speakers consistently uses {{IPA|[ŋ]}}: {{IPA|/kaɡu/}} > {{IPA|[kaŋɯ]}} (but not {{IPA|*[kaɡɯ]}}) * '''C'''. most speakers in western Japan and a smaller minority of speakers in Kantō consistently use {{IPA|[ɡ]}}: {{IPA|/kaɡu/}} > {{IPA|[kaɡɯ]}} (but not {{IPA|*[kaŋɯ]}}) '''In the middle of compound words [[morpheme]]-initially:''' * B-speakers mentioned directly above consistently use {{IPA|[ɡ]}}. So, for some speakers the following two words are a [[minimal pair]] while for others they are homophonous: * ''sengo'' {{lang|ja|千五}} (せんご) 'one thousand and five' = {{IPA|[seŋɡo]}} for B-speakers * ''sengo'' {{lang|ja|戦後}} ({{lang|ja|せんご}}) 'postwar' = {{IPA|[seŋŋo]}} for B-speakersJapanese academics represent {{IPA|[ɡo]}} as {{lang|ja|ご}} and {{IPA|[ŋo]}} as {{lang|ja|こ゜}}. To summarize using the example of ''hage'' {{lang|ja|はげ}} 'baldness': * A-speakers: {{IPA|/haɡe/}} > {{IPA|[haŋe]}} or {{IPA|[haɡe]}} or {{IPA|[haɣe]}} * B-speakers: {{IPA|/haɡe/}} > {{IPA|[haŋe]}} * C-speakers: {{IPA|/haɡe/}} > {{IPA|[haɡe]}} or {{IPA|[haɣe]}} Some phonologists posit a distinct phoneme {{IPA|/ŋ/}}, citing pairs such as {{IPA|[oːɡaɾasɯ]}} {{lang|ja|大硝子}} 'big sheet of glass' vs. {{IPA|[oːŋaɾasɯ]}} {{lang|ja|大烏}} 'big raven'.{{sfnp|Shibatani|1990|p=172}} ===Palatalization and affrication=== The palatals {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/j/}} palatalize the consonants preceding them:{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/m/}} > [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalized]] {{IPA|[mʲ]}}: | {{IPA|/umi/}} > {{IPA|[ɯmʲi]}} ''umi'' {{lang|ja|海}} 'sea' |- | {{IPA|/ɡ/}} > palatalized {{IPA|[ɡʲ]}}: | {{IPA|/ɡjoːza/}} > {{IPA|[ɡʲoːza]}} ''gyōza'' {{lang|ja|ぎょうざ}} 'fried dumpling' |- | etc. | |} For [[coronal consonant]]s, the palatalization goes further so that [[alveolo-palatal consonant]]s correspond with dental or alveolar consonants ({{IPA|[ta]}} 'field' vs. {{IPA|[t͡ɕa]}} 'tea'):{{sfnp|Itō|Mester|1995|p=827}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/n/}} > [[Alveolo-palatal nasal|Alveolo-palatal nasal]] {{IPA|[ɲ̟]}}: | {{IPA|/nihoN/}} > {{IPA|[ɲihoɴ]}} ''nihon'' {{lang|ja|日本}} 'Japan' |- | {{IPA|/s/}} > [[Voiceless alveolo-palatal fricative|alveolo-palatal fricative]] {{IPA|[ɕ]}}: | {{IPA|/sio/}} > {{IPA|[ɕi.o]}} ''shio'' {{lang|ja|塩}} 'salt' |- | style="vertical-align: top;" | {{IPA|/z/}} > [[Alveolo-palatal consonant|alveolo-palatal]] {{IPA|[d͡ʑ]}} or {{IPA|[ʑ]}}: | {{IPA|/zisiN/}} > {{IPA|[d͡ʑiɕiɴ]}} ''jishin'' {{lang|ja|地震}} 'earthquake';
{{IPA|/ɡozjuː/}} > {{IPA|[ɡod͡ʑɯː]}} ~ {{IPA|[ɡoʑɯː]}} ''gojū'' {{lang|ja|五十}} 'fifty' |- | {{IPA|/t/}} > [[Voiceless alveolo-palatal affricate|alveolo-palatal affricate]] {{IPA|[t͡ɕ]}}: | {{IPA|/tiziN/}} > {{IPA|[t͡ɕid͡ʑiɴ]}} ~ {{IPA|[t͡ɕiʑiɴ]}} ''chijin'' {{lang|ja|知人}} 'acquaintance' |} {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/j/}} also palatalize {{IPA|/h/}} to a [[Voiceless palatal fricative|palatal fricative]] ({{IPA|[ç]}}): {{IPA|/hito/}} > {{IPA|[çito]}} ''hito'' {{lang|ja|人}} ('person') Of the allophones of {{IPA|/z/}}, the [[affricate]] {{IPA|[d͡z]}} is most common, especially at the beginning of utterances and after {{IPA|/N/}}, while [[Voiced alveolar fricative|fricative]] {{IPA|[z]}} may occur between vowels. Both sounds, however, are in [[free variation]]. In the case of the {{IPA|/s/}}, {{IPA|/z/}}, and {{IPA|/t/}}, when followed by {{IPA|/j/}}, historically, the consonants were palatalized with {{IPA|/j/}} merging into a single pronunciation. In modern Japanese, these are arguably separate phonemes, at least for the portion of the population that pronounces them distinctly in English borrowings.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} :{| cellpadding="4" | {{IPA|/sj/}} > {{IPA|[ɕ]}} (romanized as ''sh''): | {{IPA|/sjaboN/}} > {{IPA|[ɕaboɴ]}} ''shabon'' {{lang|ja|シャボン}} 'soap' |- | {{IPA|/zj/}} > {{IPA|[d͡ʑ ~ ʑ]}} (romanized as ''j''): | {{IPA|/zjaɡaimo/}} > {{IPA|[d͡ʑaɡaimo]}} ''jagaimo'' {{lang|ja|じゃがいも}} 'potato' |- | {{IPA|/tj/}} > {{IPA|[t͡ɕ]}} (romanized as ''ch''): | {{IPA|/tja/}} > {{IPA|[t͡ɕa]}} ''cha'' {{lang|ja|茶}} 'tea' |- | {{IPA|/hj/}} > {{IPA|[ç]}} (romanized as ''hy''): | {{IPA|/hjaku/}} > {{IPA|[çakɯ]}} ''hyaku'' {{lang|ja|百}} 'hundred' |} The vowel {{IPA|/u/}} also affects consonants that it follows:{{sfnp|Itō|Mester|1995|p=825}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/h/}} > [[Voiceless bilabial fricative|bilabial fricative]] {{IPA|[ɸ]}}: | {{IPA|/huta/}} > {{IPA|[ɸɯta]}} ''futa'' {{lang|ja|ふた}} 'lid' |- | {{IPA|/t/}} > dental [[affricate]] {{IPA|[t͡s]}}: | {{IPA|/tuɡi/}} > {{IPA|[t͡sɯɡi]}} ''tsugi'' {{lang|ja|次}} 'next' |} Although {{IPA|[ɸ]}} and {{IPA|[t͡s]}} occur before other vowels in loanwords (e.g. {{IPA|[ɸaito]}} ''faito'' {{lang|ja|ファイト}} 'fight'; {{IPA|[ɸjɯː(d)ʑoɴ]}} ''fyūjon'' {{lang|ja|フュージョン}} 'fusion'; {{IPA|[t͡saitoɡaisɯto]}} ''tsaitogaisuto'' {{lang|ja|ツァイトガイスト}} 'Zeitgeist'; {{IPA|[eɾit͡siɴ]}} ''eritsin'' {{lang|ja|エリツィン}} '[[Boris Yeltsin|Yeltsin]]'), {{IPA|[ɸ]}} and {{IPA|[h]}} are distinguished before vowels except {{IPA|[ɯ]}} (e.g. English ''fork'' vs. ''hawk'' > ''fōku'' {{IPA|[ɸoːkɯ]}} {{lang|ja|フォーク}} vs. ''hōku'' {{IPA|[hoːkɯ]}} {{lang|ja|ホーク}}). {{IPA|*[hɯ]}} is still not distinguished from {{IPA|[ɸɯ]}} (e.g. English ''hood'' vs. ''food'' > {{IPA|[ɸɯːdo]}} ''fūdo'' {{lang|ja|フード}}).{{sfnp|Itō|Mester|1995|p=826}} Similarly, {{IPA|*[si]}} and {{IPA|*[(d)zi]}} usually do not occur even in loanwords so that English ''cinema'' becomes {{IPA|[ɕinema]}} ''shinema'' {{lang|ja|シネマ}};{{sfnp|Itō|Mester|1995|p=828}} although they may be written {{lang|ja|スィ}} and {{lang|ja|ズィ}} respectively, they are rarely found even among the most innovative speakers and do not occur phonemically.{{sfnp|Irwin|2011|p=84}}{{sfnp|Hall|2013}} ==={{IPA|/d, z/}} neutralization=== The contrast between {{IPA|/d/}} and {{IPA|/z/}} is [[Neutralization (linguistics)|neutralized]] before {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/u/}}: {{IPA|[(d)ʑi, (d)zɯ]}}. By convention, it is often assumed to be {{IPA|/z/}}, though some analyze it as {{IPA|/d͡z/}}, the [[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] counterpart to {{IPA|[t͡s]}}. The writing system preserves morphological distinctions, though spelling reform has eliminated historical distinctions except in cases where a mora is repeated once voiceless and once voiced, or where rendaku occurs in a compound word: {{lang|ja|つづく[続く]}} {{IPA|/tuduku/}}, {{lang|ja|いちづける[位置付ける]}} {{IPA|/itidukeru/}} from {{IPA|{{pipe}}iti+tukeru{{pipe}}}}. Some dialects retain the distinctions between {{IPA|/zi/}} and {{IPA|/di/}} and between {{IPA|/zu/}} and {{IPA|/du/}}, while others retain only {{IPA|/zu/}} and {{IPA|/du/}} but not {{IPA|/zi/}} and {{IPA|/di/}}, or merge all four (see [[Yotsugana]]). ===Moraic nasal=== The syllable-final moraic nasal, treated as an [[archiphoneme]] {{IPA|/N/}}, undergoes a variety of [[assimilation (linguistics)|assimilatory]] processes. It is variously:{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|pp=133–4}} * uvular {{IPA|[ɴ]}} at the end of utterances and in isolation. Dorsal occlusion may not always be complete.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=96}} * bilabial {{IPA|[m]}} before {{IPA|/p, b, m/}}; this pronunciation is also sometimes found at the end of utterances and in isolation.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} Singers are taught to pronounce all final and prevocalic instances of this sound as {{IPA|[m]}}, which reflects its historical derivation.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} * laminal {{IPA|[n]}} before [[Coronal consonant|coronals]] {{IPA|[d, t, t͡s, n]}}; never found utterance-finally. Apical {{IPA|[n̺]}} is found before liquid {{IPA|/r/}}.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=97}} * alveolo-palatal {{IPA|[ɲ]}} before alveolo-palatals {{IPA|[t͡ɕ, d͡ʑ, ɲ]}}.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=96}} * velar {{IPA|[ŋ]}} before {{IPA|/k, ɡ/}}. Before palatalized consonants, it is also palatalized, as in {{IPA|[ɡẽŋʲkʲi]}}.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=96}} * some sort of [[nasalized]] vowel before vowels, approximants {{IPA|/j, w/}}, liquid {{IPA|/r/}}, and fricatives {{IPA|[ɸ, s, ɕ, ç, h]}}. Depending on context and speaker, the vowel's quality may closely match that of the preceding vowel or be more constricted in articulation. It is thus broadly transcribed with {{IPA|[ɰ̃]}}, an ''ad hoc'' semivocalic notation undefined for the exact place of articulation.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|p=96}} It is also found utterance-finally.{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}} Some speakers produce {{IPA|[n]}} before {{IPA|/z/}}, pronouncing them as {{IPA|[nd͡z]}}, while others produce a nasalized vowel before {{IPA|/z/}}.{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997}}{{Page needed|date=May 2017}} These assimilations occur beyond word boundaries.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} ===Gemination=== While Japanese features consonant [[gemination]], there are some limitations in what can be geminated. Most saliently, voiced geminates are prohibited in native Japanese words.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=104}} This can be seen with suffixation that would otherwise feature voiced geminates. For example, Japanese has a suffix, |{{IPA|ri}}| that contains what {{Harvcoltxt|Kawahara|2006}} calls a "floating mora" that triggers gemination in certain cases (e.g. |{{IPA|tapu}}| +|{{IPA|ri}}| > {{IPA|[tappɯɾi]}} 'a lot of'). When this would otherwise lead to a geminated voiced obstruent, a moraic nasal appears instead as a sort of "partial gemination" (e.g. |{{IPA|zabu}}| + |{{IPA|ri}}| > {{IPA|[(d)zambɯɾi]}} 'splashing').{{sfnp|Kawahara|2006|p=550}}{{harvcoltxt|Labrune|2012|pp=104–5}} points out that the prefix |{{IPA|bu}}| has the same effect. In the late 20th century, voiced geminates began to appear in loanwords, though they are [[Markedness|marked]] and have a high tendency to devoicing. A frequent example is loanwords from English such as ''bed'' and ''dog'' that, though they end with voiced singletons in English, are geminated (with an epethentic vowel) when borrowed into Japanese. These geminates frequently undergo devoicing to become less marked, which gives rise to variability in voicing:{{sfn|Sano|2013|pp=245–246}} : ''doggu'' {{lang|ja|ドッグ}} → ''dokku'' {{lang|ja|ドック}} ('dog'){{sfn|Sano|2013|p=245}} : ''beddo'' {{lang|ja|ベッド}} → ''betto'' {{lang|ja|ベット}} ('bed'){{sfn|Sano|2013|p=245}} The distinction is not rigorous. For example, when voiced obstruent geminates appear with another voiced obstruent they can undergo optional devoicing (e.g. ''doreddo'' ~ ''doretto'' 'dreadlocks'). {{Harvcoltxt|Kawahara|2006}} attributes this to a less reliable distinction between voiced and voiceless geminates compared to the same distinction in non-geminated consonants, noting that speakers may have difficulty distinguishing them due to the partial devoicing of voiced geminates and their resistance to the [[#Weakening|weakening process mentioned above]], both of which can make them sound like voiceless geminates.{{sfnp|Kawahara|2006|pp=559, 561, 565}} There is some dispute about how gemination fits with Japanese [[#Phonotactics|phonotactics]]. One analysis, particularly popular among Japanese scholars, posits a special "mora phoneme" ({{lang|ja|モーラ 音素}} ''Mōra onso'') {{IPA|/Q/}}, which corresponds to the [[sokuon]] {{angbr|{{lang|ja|っ}}}}.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=135}} However, not all scholars agree that the use of this "moraic obstruent" is the best analysis. In those approaches that incorporate the moraic obstruent, it is said to completely assimilate to the following obstruent, resulting in a [[gemination|geminate]] (that is, double) consonant. The assimilated {{IPA|/Q/}} remains unreleased and thus the geminates are phonetically long consonants. {{IPA|/Q/}} does not occur before vowels or nasal consonants. This can be seen as an [[archiphoneme]] in that it has no underlying place or manner of articulation, and instead manifests as several phonetic realizations depending on context, for example: :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|[p̚]}} before {{IPA|[p]}}: | {{IPA|/ni'''Q'''.poN/}} > {{IPA|[ɲi'''p̚'''.poɴ]}} ''nippon'' {{lang|ja|日本}} 'Japan' |- | {{IPA|[s]}} before {{IPA|[s]}}: | {{IPA|/ka'''Q'''.seN/}} > {{IPA|[ka'''s'''.seɴ]}} ''kassen'' {{lang|ja|合戦}} 'battle' |- | {{IPA|[t̚]}} before {{IPA|[t͡ɕ]}}: | {{IPA|/sa'''Q'''.ti/}} > {{IPA|[sa'''t̚'''.t͡ɕi]}} ''satchi'' {{lang|ja|察知}} 'inference' |- | etc. |} Another analysis of Japanese dispenses with {{IPA|/Q/}}. In such an approach, the words above are phonemicized as shown below: :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|[p̚]}} before {{IPA|[p]}}: | {{IPA|/ni'''p'''.poN/}} > {{IPA|[ɲi'''p̚'''.poɴ]}} ''nippon'' {{lang|ja|日本}} 'Japan' |- | {{IPA|[s]}} before {{IPA|[s]}}: | {{IPA|/ka'''s'''.seN/}} > {{IPA|[ka'''s'''.seɴ]}} ''kassen'' {{lang|ja|合戦}} 'battle' |- | {{IPA|[t̚]}} before {{IPA|[t͡ɕ]}}: | {{IPA|/sa'''t'''.ti/}} > {{IPA|[sa'''t̚'''.t͡ɕi]}} ''satchi'' {{lang|ja|察知}} 'inference' |- | etc. |} Gemination can of course also be transcribed with a length mark (e.g. {{IPA|[ɲipːoɴ]}}), but this notation obscures mora boundaries. ===Sandhi=== Various forms of [[sandhi]] exist; the Japanese term for sandhi generally is {{Nihongo||連音|ren'on}}, while sandhi in Japanese specifically is called {{Nihongo||連声|renjō}}. Most commonly, a terminal {{IPA|/N/}} on one morpheme results in {{IPA|/n/}} or {{IPA|/m/}} being added to the start of the next morpheme, as in {{Nihongo||天皇|tennō|emperor}}, {{lang|ja|てん ＋ おう > てんのう}} (ten + ō = tennō). In some cases, such as this example, the sound change is used in writing as well, and is considered the usual pronunciation, though in other cases, such as abbreviating {{Nihongo||〜の家|...-no-uchi|...'s house}} to {{lang|ja|〜んち}} (''-nchi'') this is only done in speech, and considered informal. See {{lang|ja|[[:ja:連声|連声]]}} (''in Japanese'') for further examples. ==Vowels== [[File:Japanese vowel chart II.svg|thumb|upright=1.15|The vowels of Standard Japanese on a [[vowel chart]]. Adapted from {{harvcoltxt|Okada|1999|p=117}}.]] {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |+ class="nowrap" | Vowel phonemes of Japanese ! ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Central vowel|Central]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | {{IPA link|i}} || || {{IPA link|ɯᵝ|u}} |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | {{IPA link|e̞|e}} || || {{IPA link|o̞|o}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | || {{IPA link|ä|a}} || |} * {{IPA|/u/}} is a close near-back vowel with the lips unrounded ({{IPA|[ɯ̟]}}){{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=25}}{{sfnp|Akamatsu|1997|p=31}} or [[Roundedness|compressed]] ({{IPA|[ɯ̟ᵝ]}}).{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=118}}{{sfnp|Vance|2008|pp=54–6}} When compressed, it is pronounced with the side portions of the lips in contact but with no salient protrusion. In conversational speech, compression may be weakened or completely dropped.{{sfnp|Vance|2008|pp=54–6}} After {{IPA|/s, z, t/}} and palatalized consonants ({{IPA|/Cj/}}), it is centralized {{IPAblink|ɨ}}.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=25}} * {{IPA|/e, o/}} are mid {{IPA|[{{IPA link|e̞}}, {{IPA link|o̞}}]}}.{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=117}} * {{IPA|/a/}} is central {{IPAblink|ä}}.{{sfnp|Okada|1999|p=117}} Except for {{IPA|/u/}}, the short vowels are similar to their [[Spanish language|Spanish]] counterparts. Vowels have a phonemic [[vowel length|length]] contrast (i.e. short vs. long). Compare contrasting pairs of words like ''ojisan'' {{IPA|/ozisaN/}} 'uncle' vs. ''ojiisan'' {{IPA|/oziisaN/}} 'grandfather', or ''tsuki'' {{IPA|/tuki/}} 'moon' vs. ''tsūki'' {{IPA|/tuuki/}} 'airflow'. Some analyses make a distinction between a long vowel and a succession of two identical vowels, citing pairs such as {{lang|ja|砂糖屋}} ''satōya'' 'sugar shop' {{IPA|[satoːja]}} vs. {{lang|ja|里親}} ''satooya'' 'foster parent' {{IPA|[satooja]}}. They are usually identical in normal speech, but when enunciated a distinction may be made with a pause or a [[glottal stop]] inserted between two identical vowels.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|pp=45–6}} Within words and phrases, Japanese allows long sequences of phonetic vowels without intervening consonants, pronounced with [[Hiatus (linguistics)|hiatus]], although the [[Japanese pitch accent|pitch accent]] and slight rhythm breaks help track the timing when the vowels are identical. Sequences of two vowels within a single word are extremely common, occurring at the end of many ''i''-type adjectives, for example, and having three or more vowels in sequence within a word also occurs, as in ''aoi'' 'blue/green'. In phrases, sequences with multiple ''o'' sounds are most common, due to the direct object particle {{lang|ja|を}} 'wo' (which comes after a word) being realized as ''o'' and the honorific prefix {{lang|ja|お〜}} 'o', which can occur in sequence, and may follow a word itself terminating in an ''o'' sound; these may be dropped in rapid speech. A fairly common construction exhibiting these is {{lang|ja|「〜をお送りします」}} ''... (w)o o-okuri-shimasu'' 'humbly send ...'. More extreme examples follow: :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/hoo.oo.o.ou/}} {{IPA|[hoː.oː.o.oɯ]}} | ''hōō o ou'' ({{lang|ja|鳳凰を追う}}) | 'to chase a phoenix ([[Fenghuang]])' |- | {{IPA|/too.oo.o.oo.u/}} {{IPA|[toː.oː.o.oː.ɯ]}} | ''tōō o ōu'' ({{lang|ja|東欧を覆う}}) | 'to cover Eastern Europe' |} ===Devoicing=== In many dialects, the close vowels {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/u/}} become [[Voicelessness|voiceless]] when placed between two voiceless consonants or, unless accented, between a voiceless consonant and a [[pausa]].{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|pp=34–5}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/kutu/}} > {{IPA|[kɯ̥t͡sɯ]}} | ''kutsu'' {{lang|ja|靴}} 'shoe' |- | {{IPA|/atu/}} > {{IPA|[at͡sɯ̥]}} | ''atsu'' {{lang|ja|圧}} 'pressure' |- | {{IPA|/hikaN/}} > {{IPA|[çi̥kaɴ]}} | ''hikan'' {{lang|ja|悲観}} 'pessimism' |} Generally, devoicing does not occur in a consecutive manner:{{sfnp|Tsuchida|2001|p=225}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/kisitu/}} > {{IPA|[kʲi̥ɕit͡sɯ]}} | ''kishitsu'' {{lang|ja|気質}} 'temperament' |- | {{IPA|/kusikumo/}} > {{IPA|[kɯɕi̥kɯmo]}} | ''kushikumo'' {{lang|ja|奇しくも}} 'strangely' |} This devoicing is not restricted to only fast speech, though consecutive voicing may occur in fast speech.{{sfnp|Tsuchida|2001|loc=fn 3}} To a lesser extent, {{IPA|/o, a/}} may be devoiced with the further requirement that there be two or more adjacent moras containing the same phoneme:{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|pp=34–5}} :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/kokoro/}} > {{IPA|[ko̥koɾo]}} | ''kokoro'' {{lang|ja|心}} 'heart' |- | {{IPA|/haka/}} > {{IPA|[hḁka]}} | ''haka'' {{lang|ja|墓}} 'grave' |} The common sentence-ending [[copula (linguistics)|copula]] ''desu'' and polite suffix ''masu'' are typically pronounced {{IPA|[desɯ̥]}} and {{IPA|[masɯ̥]}}.{{sfnp|Seward|1992|p=9}} Japanese speakers are usually not even aware of the difference of the voiced and devoiced pair. On the other hand, gender roles play a part in prolonging the terminal vowel: it is regarded as effeminate to prolong, particularly the terminal {{IPA|/u/}} as in ''arimasu''. Some nonstandard varieties of Japanese can be recognized by their hyper-devoicing, while in some Western dialects and some registers of formal speech, every vowel is voiced.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} ===Nasalization=== Japanese vowels are slightly [[nasalization|nasalized]] when adjacent to nasals {{IPA|/m, n/}}. Before the moraic nasal {{IPA|/N/}}, vowels are heavily nasalized: :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/seesaN/}} > {{IPA|[seːsãɴ]}} | ''seisan'' {{lang|ja|生産}} 'production' |} ===Glottal stop insertion=== At the beginning and end of utterances, Japanese vowels may be preceded and followed by a [[glottal stop]] {{IPA|[ʔ]}}, respectively. This is demonstrated below with the following words (as pronounced in isolation): :{| cellpadding="3" | {{IPA|/eN/}} > {{IPA|[eɴ]}} ~ {{IPA|[ʔeɴ]}}: | ''en'' {{lang|ja|円}} 'yen' |- | {{IPA|/kisi/}} > {{IPA|[kiɕiʔ]}}: | ''kishi'' {{lang|ja|岸}} 'shore' |- | {{IPA|/u/}} > {{IPA|[ɯʔ ~ ʔɯʔ]}}: | ''u'' {{lang|ja|鵜}} 'cormorant' |} When an utterance-final word is uttered with emphasis, this glottal stop is plainly audible, and is often indicated in the writing system with a small letter ''tsu'' {{angbr|{{lang|ja|っ}}}} called a [[sokuon]]. This is also found in interjections like {{lang|ja|あっ}} and {{lang|ja|えっ}}. [ː]}} |} Japanese words have traditionally been analysed as composed of [[Mora (linguistics)#Japanese|moras]]; a distinct concept from that of syllables.Moras are represented orthographically in [[katakana]] and [[hiragana]] – each mora, with the exception of CjV clusters, being one kana – and are referred to in Japanese as 'on' or '[[onji]]'.{{Cite journal|last=Verdonschot|first=Rinus G.|last2=Kiyama|first2=Sachiko|last3=Tamaoka|first3=Katsuo|last4=Kinoshita|first4=Sachiko|last5=Heij|first5=Wido La|last6=Schiller|first6=Niels O.|title=The functional unit of Japanese word naming: Evidence from masked priming.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/a0024491|journal=Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition|language=en|volume=37|issue=6|pages=1458–1473|doi=10.1037/a0024491}} Each mora occupies one rhythmic unit, i.e. it is perceived to have the same time value.{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|p=143}} A mora may be "regular" consisting of just a vowel (V) or a consonant and a vowel (CV), or may be one of two "special" moras, {{IPA|/N/}} and {{IPA|/Q/}}. A glide {{IPA|/j/}} may precede the vowel in "regular" moras (CjV). Some analyses posit a third "special" mora, {{IPA|/R/}}, the second part of a long vowel (a [[chroneme]]).Also notated {{IPA|/H/}}, following the conventional usage of ''h'' for lengthened vowels in [[romanization of Japanese|romanization]].{{sfnp|Labrune|2012|pp=143–4}} In this table, the period represents a mora break, rather than the conventional syllable break. :{| border="0" cellspacing="3" cellpadding="4" | '''Mora type''' | '''Example''' | '''Japanese''' | '''Moras per word''' |- | V | {{IPA|/o/}} | ''o'' {{lang|ja|尾}} 'tail' | 1-mora word |- | jV | {{IPA|/jo/}} | ''yo'' {{lang|ja|世}} 'world' | 1-mora word |- | CV | {{IPA|/ko/}} | ''ko'' {{lang|ja|子}} 'child' | 1-mora word |- | CjV | {{IPA|/kjo/}}{{ref|1b|1}} | ''kyo'' {{lang|ja|巨}} 'hugeness' | 1-mora word |- | R | {{IPA|/R/}} in {{IPA|/kjo.R/}} or {{IPA|/kjo.o/}} | ''kyō'' {{lang|ja|今日}} 'today' | 2-mora word |- | N | {{IPA|/N/}} in {{IPA|/ko.N/}} | ''kon'' {{lang|ja|紺}} 'deep blue' | 2-mora word |- | Q | {{IPA|/Q/}} in {{IPA|/ko.Q.ko/}} or {{IPA|/ko.k.ko/}} | ''kokko'' {{lang|ja|国庫}} 'national treasury' | 3-mora word |} :{{note|1b|1}} Traditionally, moras were divided into plain and palatal sets, the latter of which entail [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]] of the consonant element.{{harvcoltxt|Itō|Mester|1995|p=827}}. In such a classification scheme, the plain counterparts of moras with a palatal glide are onsetless moras. {{IPA|/N/}} is restricted from occurring word-initially, and {{IPA|/Q/}} is found only word-medially.{{sfn|Aoyama|2001|p=9}} Vowels may be long, and the voiceless consonants {{IPA|/p, t, k, s, n/}} may be [[Gemination|geminate]] (doubled).{{sfn|Aoyama|2001|p=8}} In the analysis with [[archiphoneme]]s, geminate consonants are the realization of the sequences {{IPA|/Nn/}}, {{IPA|/Nm/}} and sequences of {{IPA|/Q/}} followed by a [[voiceless]] [[obstruent]], though some words are written with geminate voiced obstruents. In the analysis without archiphonemes, geminate clusters are simply two identical consonants, one after the other. In [[English language|English]], [[stress (phonology)|stress]]ed [[syllable]]s in a [[word]] are pronounced louder, longer, and with higher pitch, while unstressed syllables are relatively shorter in duration. Japanese is often considered a [[timing (linguistics)|mora-timed]] language, as each mora [[Isochrony|tends to be of the same length]],{{sfn|Aoyama|2001|pp=1–2}} though not strictly: geminate consonants and moras with devoiced vowels may be shorter than other moras.{{sfn|Aoyama|2001|p=11}} Factors such as pitch have negligible influence on mora length.{{sfn|Aoyama|2001|pp=7–8}} ==Accent== {{Main|Japanese pitch accent}} Standard Japanese has a distinctive [[pitch accent]] system: a word can have one of its moras bearing an accent or not. An accented mora is pronounced with a relatively high tone and is followed by a drop in [[pitch accent|pitch]]. The various [[Japanese dialects]] have different accent patterns, and some exhibit more complex tonic systems. ==Sound change== As an [[agglutinative language]], Japanese has generally very regular pronunciation, with much simpler [[morphophonology]] than a [[fusional language]] would. Nevertheless, there are a number of prominent sound change phenomena, primarily in morpheme combination and in conjugation of verbs and adjectives. Phonemic changes are generally reflected in the spelling, while those that are not either indicate informal or dialectal speech which further simplify pronunciation. ===Sandhi=== ====Rendaku==== {{main|Rendaku}} In Japanese, [[sandhi]] is prominently exhibited in [[rendaku]] – [[consonant mutation]] of the initial consonant of a morpheme from unvoiced to voiced in some contexts when it occurs in the middle of a word. This phonetic difference is reflected in the spelling via the addition of [[dakuten]], as in {{nihongo||か／が|ka, ga}}. In cases where this combines with the [[yotsugana]] mergers, notably {{Nihongo||じ／ぢ|ji, dzi}} and {{Nihongo||ず／づ|zu, dzu}} in standard Japanese, the resulting spelling is [[morphophonemic]] rather than purely phonemic. ====Gemination==== The other common sandhi in Japanese is conversion of {{lang|ja|つ}} or {{lang|ja|く}} (''tsu, ku''), and {{lang|ja|ち}} or {{lang|ja|き}} (''chi, ki''), and rarely {{lang|ja|ふ}} or {{lang|ja|ひ}} (''fu, hi'') as a trailing consonant to a [[geminate consonant]] when not word-final – orthographically, the [[sokuon]] {{lang|ja|っ}}, as this occurs most often with {{lang|ja|つ}}. So that * {{lang|ja|一}} (''itsu'') + {{lang|ja|緒}} (''sho'') = {{lang|ja|一緒}} (''issho'') * {{lang|ja|学}} (''gaku'') + {{lang|ja|校}} (''kō'') = {{lang|ja|学校}} (''gakkō'') Some long vowels derive from an earlier combination of a vowel and ''fu'' (see [[onbin]]). The ''f'' often causes gemination when it is joined with another word: * {{lang|ja|法}} (''hafu'' > ''hō'') + {{lang|ja|被}} (''hi'') = {{lang|ja|法被}} (''happi''), instead of ''hōhi''. * {{lang|ja|法}} (''bofu'' > ''bō'') + {{lang|ja|師}} (''shi'') = {{lang|ja|法師}} (''botchi''), sometimes ''bōshi''. * {{lang|ja|合}} (''kafu'' > ''gō'') + {{lang|ja|戦}} (''sen'') = {{lang|ja|合戦}} (''kassen''), instead of ''gōsen'' * {{lang|ja|入}} (''nifu'' > ''nyū'') + {{lang|ja|声}} (''shō'') = {{lang|ja|入声}} (''nisshō''), instead of ''nyūshō'' * {{lang|ja|十}} (''jifu'' > ''jū'') + {{lang|ja|戒}} (''kai'') = {{lang|ja|十戒}} (''jikkai'') instead of ''jūkai'' Most words exhibiting this change are [[Sino-Japanese vocabulary|Sino-Japanese]] words deriving from [[Middle Chinese]] morphemes ending in {{IPA|/t̚/}}, {{IPA|/k̚/}} or {{IPA|/p̚/}}, which were borrowed on their own into Japanese with a [[prop vowel]] after them (e.g. {{lang|ja|日}} MC *{{IPA|/nit̚/}} > Japanese {{IPA|/niti/}} {{IPA|[ɲit͡ɕi]}}) but in compounds as assimilated to the following consonant (e.g. {{lang|ja|日本}} MC *{{IPA|/nit̚.pu̯ən/}} > Japanese {{IPA|/niQ.poN/}} {{IPA|[ɲip̚.poɴ]}}). ====Renjō==== {{further2|{{lang|ja|[[:ja:連声|連声]]}}|[[Late Middle Japanese#Medial gemination]]}} Sandhi also occurs much less often in {{Nihongo||連声|renjō}}, where, most commonly, a terminal {{IPA|/N/}} or {{IPA|/Q/}} on one morpheme results in {{IPA|/n/}} (or {{IPA|/m/}} when derived from historical ''m'') or {{IPA|/t̚/}} respectively being added to the start of a following morpheme beginning with a vowel or [[semivowel]], as in {{nihongo||天皇: てん + おう → てんのう|ten + ō → tennō}}. Examples: ;First syllable ending with {{IPA|/N/}}: *{{lang|ja|銀杏}} (''ginnan''): {{lang|ja|ぎん}} (''gin'') + {{lang|ja|あん}} (''an'') → {{lang|ja|ぎん'''な'''ん}} (''gin'''n'''an'') *{{lang|ja|観音}} (''kannon''): {{lang|ja|くゎん}} (''kwan'') + {{lang|ja|おむ}} (''om'') → {{lang|ja|くゎん'''の'''む}} (''kwan'''n'''om'') → {{lang|ja|かん'''の'''ん}} (''kan'''n'''on'') *{{lang|ja|天皇}} (''tennō''): {{lang|ja|てん}} (''ten'') + {{lang|ja|わう}} (''wau'') → {{lang|ja|てん'''な'''う}} (''ten'''n'''au'') → {{lang|ja|てん'''の'''う}} (''ten'''n'''ō'') ;First syllable ending with {{IPA|/N/}} from original {{IPA|/m/}}: *{{lang|ja|三位}} (''sanmi''): {{lang|ja|さむ}} (''sam'') + {{lang|ja|ゐ}} (''wi'') → {{lang|ja|さむ'''み'''}} (''sam'''m'''i'') → {{lang|ja|さん'''み'''}} (''san'''m'''i'') *{{lang|ja|陰陽}} (''onmyō''): {{lang|ja|おむ}} (''om'') + {{lang|ja|やう}} (''yau'') → {{lang|ja|おむ'''み'''ゃう}} (''om'''m'''yau'') → {{lang|ja|おん'''み'''ょう}} (''on'''m'''yō'') ;First syllable ending with {{IPA|/Q/}}: *{{lang|ja|雪隠}} (''setchin''): {{lang|ja|せつ}} (setsu) + {{lang|ja|いん}} (''in'') → {{lang|ja|せっ'''ち'''ん}} (''set'''ch'''in) *{{lang|ja|屈惑}} (''kuttaku''): {{lang|ja|くつ}} (kutsu) + {{lang|ja|わく}} (''waku'') → {{lang|ja|くっ'''た'''く}} (''kut'''t'''aku) ===Onbin=== {{further|Japanese grammar#Euphonic changes (音便 onbin)}} Another prominent feature is {{Nihongo||音便|onbin|euphonic sound change}}, particularly historical sound changes. In cases where this has occurred within a morpheme, the morpheme itself is still distinct but with a different sound, as in {{Nihongo||箒 (ほうき)|hōki|broom}}, which underwent two sound changes from earlier {{Nihongo||ははき|hahaki}} → {{Nihongo||はうき|hauki}} (onbin) → {{Nihongo||ほうき|houki}} (historical vowel change) → {{Nihongo||ほうき|hōki}} (long vowel, sound change not reflected in kana spelling). However, certain forms are still recognizable as irregular morphology, particularly forms that occur in basic verb conjugation, as well as some compound words. ====Verb conjugation==== {{further2|[[Japanese grammar#Verb conjugations|Onbin in verb conjugations]]}} ====Polite adjective forms==== {{further|Japanese grammar#Polite forms of adjectives}} The [[Japanese grammar#Polite forms of adjectives|polite adjective forms]] (used before the polite copula {{nihongo||ござる|gozaru|be}} and verb {{nihongo||存じる|zonjiru|think, know}}) exhibit a one-step or two-step sound change. Firstly, these use the continuative form, {{Nihongo||-く|-ku}}, which exhibits ''onbin'', dropping the ''k'' as {{Nihongo||-く|-ku}} → {{Nihongo||-う|-u}}. Secondly, the vowel may combine with the preceding vowel, according to historical sound changes; if the resulting new sound is palatalized, meaning {{nihongo||ゆ、よ|yu, yo}}, this combines with the preceding consonant, yielding a palatalized syllable. This is most prominent in certain everyday terms that derive from an ''i''-adjective ending in ''-ai'' changing to ''-ō'' (''-ou''), which is because these terms are abbreviations of polite phrases ending in ''gozaimasu'', sometimes with a polite ''o-'' prefix. The terms are also used in their full form, with notable examples being: * {{nihongo||有難う、ありがとう|arigatō|Thank you}}, from {{nihongo||有難い、ありがたい|arigatai|(I am) grateful}}. * {{nihongo||お早う、おはよう|ohayō|Good morning}}, from {{nihongo||早い、はやい|hayai|(It is) early}}. * {{nihongo||お目出度う、おめでとう|omedetō|Congratulations}}, from {{nihongo||目出度い、めでたい|medetai|(It is) auspicious}}. Other transforms of this type are found in polite speech, such as {{Nihongo||美味しく|oishiku}} → {{Nihongo||美味しゅう|oishū}} and {{Nihongo||大きく|ōkiku}} → {{Nihongo||大きゅう|ōkyū}}. ====''-hito''==== The morpheme {{nihongo||人 (ひと)|hito|person}} (with ''rendaku'' {{nihongo||〜びと|-bito}}) has changed to {{nihongo||うと|uto}} or {{nihongo||うど|udo}}, respectively, in a number of compounds. This in turn often combined with a historical vowel change, resulting in a pronunciation rather different from that of the components, as in {{Nihongo||仲人 (なこうど)|nakōdo|matchmaker}} (see below). These include: * {{Nihongo||弟 (おとうと)|otōto|younger brother}}, from {{Nihongo||弟人 (おとひと)|otohito}} → {{Nihongo||おとうと|otouto}} → {{Nihongo|||otōto}}. * {{Nihongo||妹 (いもうと)|imōto|younger sister}}, from {{Nihongo||妹人 (いもひと)|imohito}} → {{Nihongo||いもうと|imouto}} → {{Nihongo|||imōto}}. * {{Nihongo||素人 (しろうと)|shirōto|novice}}, from {{Nihongo||白人 (しろひと)|shirohito}} → {{Nihongo||しろうと|shirouto}} → {{Nihongo|||shirōto}}. * {{Nihongo||玄人 (くろうと)|kurōto|veteran}}, from {{Nihongo||黒人 (くろひと)|kurohito}} → {{Nihongo||くろうと|kurouto}} → {{Nihongo|||kurōto}}. * {{Nihongo||仲人 (なこうど)|nakōdo|matchmaker}}, from {{Nihongo||仲人 (なかびと)|nakabito}} → {{Nihongo||なかうど|nakaudo}} → {{Nihongo||なこうど|nakoudo}} → {{Nihongo|||nakōdo}}. * {{Nihongo||狩人 (かりゅうど)|karyūdo|hunter}}, from {{Nihongo||狩人 (かりびと)|karibito}} → {{Nihongo||かりうど|kariudo}} → {{Nihongo||かりゅうど|karyuudo}} → {{Nihongo|||karyūdo}}. * {{Nihongo||舅 (しゅうと)|shūto|stepfather}}, from {{Nihongo||舅人 (しひと)|shihito}} → {{Nihongo||しうと|shiuto}} → {{Nihongo||しゅうと|shuuto}} → {{Nihongo|||shūto}}. ====Fusion==== In some cases morphemes have effectively fused and will not be recognizable as being composed of two separate morphemes.{{Citation revision.text:
'''John Lucas Perreault''' ([[New York City|New York, NY]], August 26, 1937–September 6, 2015, New York, NY), was a poet, art curator, art critic, and artist.
==Early life== Perreault was born in [[Manhattan]] and raised in [[Belmar, New Jersey|Belmar]] and other towns in New Jersey.<ref name=Grimes>{{cite journal|title=John Perreault, Art Critic (and Artist) Who Championed the New, Dies at 78|last=Grimes|first=William|journal=The New York Times|date=8 September 2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/09/arts/john-perreault-critic-artist-and-poet-dies-at-78.html|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> He studied briefly at [[Montclair State University|Montclair State Teachers College]], after which he enrolled in a poetry workshop at the [[New School for Social Research]].<ref name=Grimes/> His first book of poetry, ''Camouflage'', was published in 1966, followed by ''Luck'' (1969) and ''Harry'' (1974).<ref name=Grimes/>
==Professional work== Perreault was an editorial associate for ''[[ARTnews]]'' in the 1960s, an art critic for ''[[Village Voice|The Village Voice]]'' (1966-74), and senior art critic for ''The Soho Weekly News'' (1975-82).<ref name=Greenberger>{{cite web|title=John Perreault, Noted Art Critic for The Village Voice and ARTnews, Dies at 78|last=Greenberger|first=Alex|website=ARTnews|url=http://www.artnews.com/2015/09/08/john-perreault-noted-art-critic-for-the-village-voice-and-artnews-dies-at-78/|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> He also worked briefly as the chief curator at the [[Everson Museum]] (1982).<ref name=Grimes/> From 1985 to 1989, he was the first professional curator at the [[Sailors' Snug Harbor|Newhouse Center for Contemporary Art]] in [[Staten Island]].<ref name=Grimes/><ref name=Fressola>{{cite journal|title=John Perreault, first curator at Snug Harbor's Newhouse, dies at 78|last=Fressola|first=Michael J.|journal=The Staten Island Advance|date=8 September 2015|url=http://www.silive.com/entertainment/arts/index.ssf/2015/09/john_perreault_ex-curator_at_s.html|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> He was also senior curator at the [[Museum of Arts and Design|American Craft Museum]] (1990-93).<ref name=Grimes/><ref name=Fressola/> In later years, Perreault was interested in [[craft]] and served as the executive director of UrbanGlass.<ref name=Greenberger/> From 2004 until 2014, he wrote a [[blog]] called ''Artopia: John Perreault's art diary''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Artopia: John Perreault's art diary|last=Perreault|first=John|url=http://www.artsjournal.com/artopia|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref>
==Art and art criticism== As an art critic, Perreault's writing was clear and accessible.<ref name=Voice/><ref name=Littman>{{cite journal|title=John Perreault|last=Littman|first=Brett|journal=The Brooklyn Rail|date=1 November 2016|url=http://brooklynrail.org/2016/11/criticspage/john-perreault|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Deadpan humor with a point of view: Why critic John Perreault will be missed|last=Miranda|first=Carolina A.|journal=Los Angeles Times|date=20 December 2015|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/miranda/la-et-cam-why-critic-john-perreault-will-be-missed-20150909-column.html|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> He championed the [[avant garde]], including [[Minimalism]], [[Land art|Land Art]], and [[Pattern and Decoration|Pattern & Decoration]].<ref name=Greenberger/> In 1968, when several names were used to describe the art now known as Minimalism, he predicted that the term ''minimalism'' would "stick."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Plastic Ambiguities|last=Perreault|first=John|journal=The Village Voice|date=7 March 1968}}</ref>
In the 1970s, with the rise of the [[feminist art movement]], he frequently wrote in support of art by women.<ref name=Grimes/><ref name=Voice>{{cite journal|title=John Perreault, Artist, Critic, and Author, 1937-2015|last=Village Voice Staff|date=9 September 2015|journal=The Village Voice|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2015/09/09/john-perreault-artist-critic-and-author-1937-2015/|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref><ref name=Goldstein>{{cite web|title='It's Only Art' Proves the Late Village Voice Critic John Perreault Was Witty With the Brush as Well as the Pen|last=Goldstein|first=Andrew|website=Artnet News|date=7 July 2017|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/john-perreault-at-marquee-projects-1017152|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> In 1974, for example, he praised [[Sylvia Sleigh|Sylvia Sleigh's]] recent nudes, calling them "as daring as ever, perhaps even a little bit more daring" and noting that she was "always willing to challenge herself and her viewers."<ref>{{cite journal|title=Acute linoleum heartburn|last=Perreault|first=John|journal=The Village Voice|date=26 September 1974|page=40}}</ref> The following year, he responded positively to [[Shirley Gorelick|Shirley Gorelick's]] paintings of [[African-Americans|African-American]] sitters.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Outrageous Black Pop|last=Perreault|first=John|journal=The Soho Weekly News|date=1 May 1975|page=19}}</ref> In his review of a group show at [[Soho20 Chelsea|SOHO20]] called ''Showing Off'' (1975), Perreault characterized [[Sharon Wybrants|Sharon Wybrants's]] ''Self-Portrait as Superwoman (Woman as Culture Hero)'' (1975) as "more than slightly tongue-in-cheek. But it demonstrates that women artists have egos too, sometimes just as big as any man's. And why shouldn’t they?"<ref name=Perreault1>{{cite journal|title=Superwoman!|last=Perreault|first=John|journal=The Soho Weekly News|date=25 September 1975}}</ref> Perreault also praised [[Alice Neel]]'s portrait of the [[art history|art historian]] [[Linda Nochlin]] (now at the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=Linda Nochlin and Daisy|last=Neel|first=Alice|date=1973|url=https://www.mfa.org/collections/object/linda-nochlin-and-daisy-36578|accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref> calling it "a knock-out" and remarking that "Nochlin looks as if she has just had about enough of [[Gustave Courbet|Courbet]], whereas her daughter is the perfect imp."<ref>{{cite journal|journal=The Soho Weekly News|last=Perreault|first=John|title=Talking Heads: Portraiture Revived|date=19 February 1976}}</ref>
At times, Perreault served as a subject for artists,<ref name=Russeth/> including [[Alice Neel]], whose ''John Perreault'' (1972) is now owned by the [[Whitney Museum of American Art]].<ref>{{cite web|title=John Perreault|last=Neel|first=Alice|date=1972|url=http://collection.whitney.org/object/2447}}</ref> The two met when Perreault was working for ''ARTnews'', but the portrait was painted for ''The Male Nude'' (1973), an exhibition that Perreault curated at the [[School of Visual Arts]].<ref name=Newhall>{{cite journal|title=Neel Life Stories|last=Newhall|first=Edith|journal=New York Magazine|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/features/3409/|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> As he later recalled, Neel thought he resembled a [[faun]].<ref name=Newhall/> Perreault also appears with other art critics—all unclothed—in Sylvia Sleigh's ''The Turkish Bath'' (1973).<ref>{{cite web|title=As Portraits Became Passé, These Artists Redefined 'Face Value'|last=Stamberg|first=Susan|website=NPR|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/05/29/316408346/as-portraits-became-pass-these-artists-redefined-face-value|date=29 May 2014|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> Perreault was later portrayed in Sleigh's 14-panel ''Invitation to a Voyage: The Hudson River at Fishkill'' (1979-99), now owned by the [[Hudson River Museum]].<ref name=Russeth>{{cite web|title=Invitation to a Voyage: On Sylvia Sleigh's Other Portrait of the Late Art Critic John Perreault|last=Russeth|first=Andrew|website=ARTnews|url=http://www.artnews.com/2015/09/14/john-perreault-portrait-sylvia-sleigh/|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> In 1975, a bust-length portrait of Perreault was painted by [[Philip Pearlstein]].<ref name=Greenberger/> Perreault later wrote a monograph on Pearlstein's drawings and watercolors, published in 1988.<ref>{{cite book|title=Philip Pearlstein: Drawings and Watercolors|last=Perreault|first=John|publisher=Harry N. Abrams, Inc.|place=New York|date=1988}}</ref>
Like other art critics, including [[John Ruskin]] and [[Clement Greenberg]], John Perreault was also an artist.<ref name=Goldstein/> He created drawings, paintings, and [[found object]] constructions.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Element of Chance: A Celebration of John Perreault|last=Baker|first=R.C.|website=The Village Voice|date=11 July 2017|url=https://www.villagevoice.com/2017/07/11/an-element-of-chance-a-celebration-of-john-perreault/|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> Perreault's first exhibition of paintings and sculptures was in 1965.<ref name=Perreault>{{cite web|title=Portfolio|last=Perreault|first=John|url=http://johnperreault.info/portfolio.html|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref> Later, he aimed "to attack what he calls the art supplies racket" by using "alternate media," such as [[Colgate (toothpaste)|Colgate toothpaste]] and oil-soaked beach sand.<ref name=Perreault/> Another preferred medium was instant coffee grounds,<ref name=Goldstein/> which he used "in honor of" [[George Washington (inventor)|George Washington]], "the 'inventor' of instant coffee," who once maintained a residence near [[Bellport, New York]], where Perreault lived.<ref name=Perreault/>
==Personal life== In 2008, Perreault married Jeff Weinstein, his partner of 32 years, in [[Provincetown, Massachusetts]], after [[Same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]] was legalized there.<ref name=Sipher>{{cite journal|title=Vows: Jeff Weinstein and John Perreault|last=Sipher|first=Devan|journal=The New York Times|date=20 December 2008|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/21/fashion/weddings/21Vows.html|accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref> Weinstein, who began as a restaurant critic, has held positions as an arts editor at ''The Soho Weekly News'' (1977-79), editor of visual arts and architecture criticism at ''The Village Voice'' (1981-95), fine arts editor at ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' (1997-2006), and editor of arts and culture at [[Bloomberg News]] (2006-07).<ref name=Weinstein>{{cite web|title=Out There: Jeff Weinstein's Cultural Mixology|last=Weinstein|first=Jeff|url=http://www.artsjournal.com/outthere/jeff-weinstein|accessdate=3 October 2017}}</ref>
==Death== Perreault died in 2015, aged 78, from complications following [[digestive system surgery|gastrointestinal surgery]].<ref name=Grimes/>
==References== {{Reflist}}

'''Basil cultivars''' are cultivated [[Variety (biology)|varieties]] of [[basil]]. They are used in a variety of ways: as culinary herbs, landscape plants, healing herbs, teas, and worship implements. All true basils are [[species]] of the genus ''[[Ocimum]]''. The genus is particularly diverse, and includes [[annual plant|annuals]], non-woody [[perennial plant|perennials]] and [[shrub]]s native to [[Africa]] and other [[tropics|tropical]] and [[subtropics|subtropical]] regions of the [[Old World|Old]] and [[New World]].{{cite web |title=Basil: An Herb Society of America Guide |url=http://www.herbsociety.org/basil/bdesc.php |publisher=Herb Society of America |accessdate=2006-12-30 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061208235816/http://www.herbsociety.org/basil/bdesc.php |archivedate=2006-12-08 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Although it is estimated that there are 50 to 150 species of basil,{{cite conference | url=http://www.hort.purdue.edu/newcrop/proceedings1990/V1-484.html | author=Simon, J.E., J. Quinn, and R.G. Murray | year=1990 | title=Basil: A source of essential oils | pages=484–489 |editor1=J. Janick |editor2=J.E. Simon | booktitle=Advances in new crops | publisher=Timber Press, Portland, OR. }}The Herb Garden, in the [[United States National Arboretum]], showcases some 25 varieties of basil every year. The Herb Garden was a gift to the United States from the [[Herb Society of America]]. most, but not all, culinary basils are [[cultivar]]s of ''O. basilicum'', or [[sweet basil]]. Some are cultivars of other basil species, and others are [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]]. It is particularly challenging to determine which species a basil belongs to. This is because basil cross-breeds easily, and drawing boundaries between species is particularly difficult. In fact, recent studies have led to reclassification of some portions of the genus.{{cite conference | author=Paton, Alan, R.M. Harley and M.M. Harley | year=1999 | title=Ocimum: an overview of classification and relationships | booktitle=Basil: the genus Ocimum |editor1=Edited by Raimo Hiltunen |editor2=Yvonne Holm | publisher=Australia: Harwood Academic Publishers | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nhF71j9doqsC }} Basil cultivars vary in several ways. Visually, the size and shape of the leaves varies greatly, from the large lettuce-like leaves of the ''Mammoth basil'' and ''Lettuce leaf basil'' to the tiny leaves of the ''Dwarf bush basil''. More practically, the fragrance of the basil varies due to the varying types and quantities of [[essential oil]]s contained in the plants. The most important are 1,8 [[cineol]], [[linalool]], [[citral]], methyl chavicol ([[estragole]]), [[eugenol]] and [[methyl cinnamate]], although hardly any basil contains all of these in any significant amount. ==Basil cultivars== [[File:Ocimum tenuiflorum2.jpg|thumb|Holy basil]] [[File:Basil-PWittal.JPG|thumb|Sweet basil growing in the sun]] [[File:Thai basil flower.jpg|thumb|Late summer Thai basil flowers]] [[File:Basil leaves.jpg|thumb|Harvested sweet basil leaves]] [[File:Bush basil AKA manjerico.jpg|thumb|Greek Bush Basil]] {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="3" style="background-color:#efe;font-size:120%;" | ''Ocimum basilicum'' cultivars |- ! == 1930s == * '''[[1930 in television|1930]]''': Baird installs a television at [[10 Downing Street]], [[London]], the [[British Prime Minister]]'s residence. On July 14, Prime Minister [[Ramsay MacDonald]] and his family use it to watch the first ever television drama, ''[[The Man with the Flower in His Mouth]]''. * '''[[1931 in television|1931]]''': [[Allen B. DuMont]] perfects long-lasting reliable cathode ray tubes later used for television reception. TV reaches the [[Soviet Union]] and [[French Third Republic|France]]. * '''[[1932 in television|1932]]''': The [[BBC]] starts a regular public television broadcasting service in the UK. * '''[[1933 in television|1933]]''': The first television revue, ''[[Looking In (TV series)|Looking In]]'', is broadcast on the [[British Broadcasting Company|BBC]]. The musical revue featured the Paramount Astoria dancing girls. Broadcast live by the BBC using John Logie Baird's 30-line mechanical television system, part of this performance was recorded onto a 7" aluminum disc using a primitive home recording process called [[Silvatone]]. This footage, which runs to just under four minutes, is the oldest surviving recording of broadcast television. * '''[[1934 in television|1934]]''': [[Philo Farnsworth]] demonstrates a non-mechanical television system. The agreement for joint experimental transmissions by the BBC and John Logie Baird's company comes to an end. First 30 Line Mechanical Television Test Transmissions commence in April in Brisbane Australia conducted by Thomas Elliott and Dr [[Val McDowall]]. * '''[[1935 in television|1935]]''': First regular scheduled TV broadcasts in [[Germany]] by the [[Fernsehsender Paul Nipkow|TV Station Paul Nipkow]]. The final transmissions of [[John Logie Baird]]'s 30-line television system are broadcast by the BBC. First TV broadcasts in France on February 13 on [[Paris PTT Vision]]. * '''[[1936 in television|1936]]''': The [[1936 Summer Olympics]] becomes the first Olympic Games to be broadcast on television. * '''[[1937 in television|1937]]''': The [[BBC One|BBC Television Service]] broadcasts the world's first televised [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] play, a thirty-minute version of ''[[Twelfth Night]]'', and the first [[Association football|football]] match, [[Arsenal F.C.]] vs. Arsenal reserves. * '''[[1938 in television|1938]]''': [[DuMont Laboratories]] manufactures and sells the first all-electronic television sets to the public. Baird gives the first public demonstration of color projection television. The [[British Broadcasting Company|BBC]] broadcasts the world's first ever [[Science fiction on television|television science fiction]] (''[[R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots)|R.U.R.]]''), and television crime series (''[[Telecrime]]''); in one of the lengthiest experimental television broadcasts, the BBC broadcasts a 90-minute version of [[Edmond Rostand]]'s ''[[Cyrano de Bergerac (play)|Cyrano de Bergerac]]'', starring [[Leslie Banks]], [[Constance Cummings]], and [[James Mason]]. * '''[[1939 in television|1939]]''': The BBC suspends its television service owing to the outbreak of the [[Second World War]]. The [[1939 New York World's Fair]] was broadcast. [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] is the first Asian country to air television.
==1940s== *'''[[1940 in television|1940]]''': the American [[Federal Communications Commission]], ([[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]]), holds public hearings on television *'''[[1941 in television|1941]]''': First [[television advertisement]]s aired. The first official, paid television advertisement was broadcast in the United States on July 1, 1941 over New York station WNBT (now WNBC) before a baseball game between the Brooklyn Dodgers and Philadelphia Phillies. The announcement was for Bulova watches. *'''[[1942 in television|1942]]''': [[Federal Communications Commission|FCC]] terminates all American television broadcasting because of the war; DuMont petitions FCC to resume broadcasting and receives approval *'''[[1943 in television|1943]]''': ''[[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)|Hänsel und Gretel]]'' is the first complete [[opera]] to be broadcast on television, but only in New York; first (experimental) telecast of [[Charles Dickens]]'s ''[[A Christmas Carol]]''. Many more telecasts of the story will follow in later years, but until film begins to be used on television, no two of the television versions of the story will have the same casts. *'''[[1944 in television|1944]]''': [[American Broadcasting Company]], [[American Broadcasting Company|(ABC]]), is formed. *'''[[1945 in television|1945]]''': [[National Broadcasting Company]] ([[NBC]]) begins the first regularly scheduled television network service in the United States. *'''[[1946 in television|1946]]''': [[RCA]] demonstrates all-electronic [[color television]] system; the [[DuMont Television Network]] begins broadcasting. *'''[[1947 in television|1947]]''': First broadcast of ''[[Howdy Doody]]'', ''[[Kraft Television Theatre]]'' and ''[[Meet the Press]]''; the [[World Series]] is broadcast live for the first time; the 1947 ''[[Tournament of Roses Parade]]'' becomes the very first parade ever televised. *'''[[1948 in television|1948]]''': First broadcast of ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' and ''[[Texaco Star Theater]]'' *'''[[1949 in television|1949]]''': First broadcast of ''[[The Lone Ranger (TV series)|The Lone Ranger]]'', ''[[Crusader Rabbit]]'' and ''[[Mama (TV series)|Mama]]''; the [[1st Primetime Emmy Awards|first]] [[Emmy Award]]s are given.

'''Main tapal empat''' is a two-player [[abstract strategy]] [[board game]] from [[Malaysia]].<ref name="WintherMainTapalEmpat">{{cite web|last1=Winther|first1=Mats|title=Asian Tiger games hunt games from Asia|url=http://mlwi.magix.net/bg/asiantiger.htm|website=Asian Tiger games|publisher=August 2006|accessdate=2016-06-26}}</ref> It is a hunt game, and specifically a tiger hunt game (or tiger game) since it uses an Alquerque board. The tigers can move as many spaces in a straight line as a clear path allows.<ref name=WintherMainTapalEmpat/> Most hunt games have tigers, leopards, or foxes moving only one space at a time. In effect, the tigers in this game have the movement capability of the [[Queen (chess)|queen]] in [[chess]].
== Setup ==
The game uses a standard [[Alquerque]] board. Two tigers and eighteen goats are represented by distinguishable pieces, usually black and white respectively.
Players decide who will play the tigers and the goats.
The board is empty in the beginning.
== Rules ==
* Players alternate their turns throughout the game. * The two tigers are placed on any two intersection points on the central square of the Alquerque board. * Goats are then dropped on the board one piece per turn on any vacant intersection point on the board. * The goats on the board cannot move until all 18 of their pieces are dropped on the board which requires 18 turns. The tigers however can move and capture goat pieces from the beginning. * Tigers move or capture exclusively in a turn following the pattern on the board. **Tigers can move (in any available direction) as far as they want on a straight line as long as the path is unoccupied onto a vacant intersection point. Only one tiger may be moved in a turn. **Alternatively, the tiger can capture a goat. Tigers can capture by the short leap as in [[draughts]] and [[Alquerque]]. The leap can only be done if the tiger is already adjacent to the goat at the beginning of its turn. The tiger cannot move (next to a goat) and then leap. Nor can it leap over an adjacent goat, and then move. The tiger must either move or leap exclusively on its turn. To perform the short leap method the tiger leaps over the adjacent goat, and lands on a vacant intersection point adjacently behind the goat that was leaped over. The leap must follow the pattern on the board, and it must be done in a straight line. Only one goat may be captured in a turn, and is removed from the board. Captures are not compulsory. * Goats move following the pattern on the board. Only one goat may be moved per turn. A goat moves (in any available direction) along a marked line onto a vacant adjacent intersection point. * The goats win if they block the movements of the tigers such that the tigers cannot perform a legal move or capture. * The tigers win if they capture enough of the goats so that the goats cannot effectively block the movements of the tigers, and this is usually when the number of goats are reduced to 10.<ref name=WintherMainTapalEmpat/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Nation Estate | film name = | director = [[Larissa Sansour]] | producer = Morten Revsgaard Frederiksen Beofilm Productions ApS | writer = Søren Lind | cinematography = Jesper Tøffner | starring = {{Plain list| * Larissa Sansour * Leila Sansour * Maxim Sansour }} | music = Aida Nadeem | editing = William Dybeck Sorensen | released = 2013 | runtime = 9 minutes | country = [[State of Palestine|Palestine]]/[[Denmark]] | language = Arabic/English }}
'''''Nation Estate''''' is a 2013 [[Culture of Palestine|Palestinian]] movie directed by Larissa Sansour. It is a sci-fi short film that depicts Palestine as a skyscraper, with each floor representing a city in Palestine. An earlier version of the project garnered attention when it was removed from a competition at the [[Musée de l'Elysée]] allegedly due to its political connotations.<ref name="Independent">{{cite web|last=Milmo|first=Cahal|title=Lacoste accused of attempting to censor 'too pro-Palestinian' art|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/lacoste-accused-of-attempting-to-censor-too-propalestinian-art-6280082.html|work=The Independent}}</ref>
== Plot ==
The film starts with a pregnant woman arriving at a train station. She makes her way up an escalator with a travel bag in hand. At the top of the escalator she uses a fingerprint and retinal scan to enter a lobby and walks over to the elevators. As she pushes the button, she looks over to a poster on the wall that reads "Nation Estate: Living the High Life". Next to the elevator is a directory for the building floors. Each floor is described as a city or area in Palestine. In the elevator, advertisements play on a television screen. The advertisements seems to address different social and political issues that Palestinians face today, such as water supply, food and travelling restrictions. The first stop the elevator makes is on the 13th floor, [[Jerusalem]]. As two other 'travelers' make their way off the elevator, you can see the [[Al-Aqsa Mosque]]. The next stop is [[Bethlehem]]. As the woman steps off the elevator and walks away, the city's old architecture can be seen as the basis for the floor. She walks into a tunnel that seems to be authentic stone and mortar from the outside, but is more modern on the inside. She stops at a door, and using a keycard in the form of a Palestinian flag, she opens up the door to an apartment. She sets the keycard down, and picks up a watering can. She heads over to a window, and in front of the window, there is a tree growing out of the ground and she waters it. Afterwards, she heads over to a cabinet and opens it up, revealing multicolored cans. When she grabs one and looks at it, it has a label that says '[[Mulukhiyah|Mloukhieh]]', a food native to the Middle East and North Africa. She returns the can and reaches for another, this time it is 'Marmaon'. She heats it up using a fingerprint and pours it out into a bowl, along with other food. She sets it down on the table and makes her way to the window. After pressing a button on the wall, the view changes into one of Jerusalem. The woman holds her belly as she looks on to the city.
== Controversy ==
In 2011, a multimedia project of the same name by the film’s director, [http://www.larissasansour.com Larissa Sansour], was selected to be a part of the [[Lacoste]] Elysée Competition. However, after being shortlisted for a prize by the museum, Larissa was contacted by the museum staff, informing her that her film was deemed "too pro-Palestinian" by the people from Lacoste, allegations which the company later denied.<ref name="Independent" /> The museum also requested that Sansour release a statement saying that she had "decided to pursue other opportunities."<ref name="Independent" />
After the work’s removal sparked outrage, Lacoste ended its sponsorship of the £21,000 prize while the gallery in turn suspended its relationship with the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-16299688|title=Censorship row cancels art prize|date=2011-12-22|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-04-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
== Film Festivals ==
* Prize of the Ecumenical Jury – Oberhausen International Short Film Festival 2013<ref name="FF">{{cite web|title=Nation Estate|url=http://www.bieff.ro/film/25#Awards|work=Bucharest International Experimental Film Festival}}</ref> * Rotterdam International Film Festival 2013<ref name="FF" /> * Best Short Film of the Critics Jury – International Festival of Arab Cinemas Marseille 2013<ref name="FF" /> * International Oriental Film Festival Geneva 2013<ref name="FF" /> * Bucharest International Experimental Film Festival 2013<ref name="FF" />
